writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey stared out the window of his sleek, high-rise apartment, the Manhattan skyline twinkling like a scattering of diamonds against the evening sky. It was a view he'd grown accustomed to, one that reflected the life he'd built as a master art forger turned FBI consultant. But as he stood there, lost in thought, the city lights seemed to blur and fade, replaced by the familiar glow of a dimly lit art studio, the smell of turpentine and linseed oil transporting him back to a different life.

A life he thought he'd left behind.

The phone on his kitchen counter buzzed, shrill in the silence. Neal's heart quickened as he recognized the number flashing on the screen. Mozzie. His old partner, his friend, his... complicated past.

"Hey, Moz," Neal answered, trying to sound casual despite the tension coiling in his stomach.

"Neal, my friend, I have a proposition for you," Mozzie said, his voice low and smooth as silk. "A little job, just like old times."

Neal's instincts screamed warning, but he found himself listening, intrigued, as Mozzie outlined the plan. A rare, priceless artifact, a wealthy collector willing to pay top dollar... It was the kind of score they used to dream about, the kind that would have set them up for life.

But something didn't feel right.

"Moz, I don't know," Neal said, hesitating for the first time in his life when it came to a heist. "This feels... off."

There was a pause on the other end of the line, and for a moment, Neal wondered if he'd misread the situation entirely. But then Mozzie's voice came back, laced with amusement.

"Come on, Neal. You're not going to tell me you've gone straight, are you? That the FBI's got you on a leash and you can't even think about a little creative entrepreneurship?"

Neal's gut twisted. That was exactly what he was thinking. He'd worked hard to build a new life, to prove to himself and everyone else that he was more than just a con artist. But the temptation was there, lurking just beneath the surface, whispering that he could have it all – the thrill of the heist, the satisfaction of outsmarting the system, and the comfort of his new, respectable life.

Over the next few days, Neal found himself torn. He went through the motions at the FBI, working with Peter and the team on a string of low-level cases, but his mind kept drifting back to Mozzie's proposal. He knew he couldn't do it, not without jeopardizing everything he'd built, but a part of him ached to take the risk.

It wasn't until he was working late one night, staring at a forgery case that was going nowhere, that he realized the truth. He wasn't just hesitant because of the FBI or the law; he was hesitant because of himself. He'd always defined himself by his skills, his charm, and his ability to talk his way out of any situation. But what if that wasn't who he was anymore?

The question echoed in his mind like a mantra, until finally, he picked up the phone and dialed Mozzie's number.

"Moz, I'm out," he said, the words feeling both liberating and terrifying.

There was a pause, and for a moment, Neal wondered if he'd made a mistake. But then Mozzie's voice came back, tinged with a mix of disappointment and understanding.

"I knew it, Neal. You're not the same guy I used to know."

Neal smiled wryly to himself. Maybe that was the point.

As he hung up the phone, the city lights outside seemed to snap back into focus, brighter and more vibrant than before. He'd made a choice, one that reflected the person he was becoming – imperfect, maybe, but honest. And as he turned back to the forgery case, a plan began to form in his mind, one that would use his old skills for a new purpose.

The game was far from over, but for the first time in a long time, Neal felt like he was playing by his own rules.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley adjusted his cufflinks as he stepped into the crowded restaurant, his eyes scanning the room for a familiar face. It had been years since he'd last seen Dean Winchester, and he hadn't exactly been expecting to run into him here, of all places. But as he spotted the hunter sitting at the bar, nursing a whiskey on the rocks, a spark of curiosity ignited within him.

As he made his way over, Dean looked up and caught his eye, a hint of surprise flickering across his face before he raised his glass in a silent toast. Crowley smiled, intrigued by the unspoken invitation, and slid onto the stool beside him.

"Long time no see, Dean," he said, signaling the bartender for a drink.

Dean turned to him, his eyes narrowing slightly as he replied, "Crowley. I might've known you'd turn up eventually."

Their banter was as easy as ever, but Crowley detected a undercurrent of tension beneath the surface. He probed gently, sensing that Dean was hiding something. "What brings you to this humble establishment? Not exactly your usual haunt, is it?"

Dean snorted. "Just passing through. I've got a meeting with some... associates."

Crowley's ears perked up at the hesitation. "Associates, you say? Sounds like a delightful euphemism. Federal agents, perhaps?"

Dean's eyes locked onto his, a glint of warning flashing in their depths. "You know as well as I do, Crowley, that I don't mix with your kind."

The words stung, but Crowley let them roll off his back. He'd grown accustomed to Dean's prickly exterior over the years. "Ah, but that's where you're wrong, my dear hunter. I'm not just any demon. I'm the one who's going to help you navigate this mess."

As the night wore on, Crowley found himself drawn into Dean's orbit, listening intently as the hunter poured out his frustrations with the federal agents breathing down his neck. It wasn't until the restaurant began to close that Crowley realized the hours had slipped away, leaving only the two of them lingering at the bar.

As they stepped out into the cool night air, Dean turned to him, his voice low and hesitant. "Crowley, I... I need your help. I know it's a lot to ask, but –"

Crowley's fingers brushed against Dean's, sending a spark of electricity through his veins. "I'm listening, Dean. What do you need me to do?"

The words hung in the air, heavy with unspoken promise, as Crowley's eyes met Dean's. For a moment, the world around them melted away, leaving only the thrum of possibility.

The next thing Crowley knew, they were kissing, the stolen moment a jolt of pure adrenaline. As they broke apart, gasping, Dean's eyes searched his, seeking reassurance.

Crowley's smile was a slow, wicked thing. "I think, Dean, that we're in this together now. Whether you like it or not."

The days that followed were a whirlwind of federal agents, family barbecues, and whispered conversations in the dead of night. Crowley found himself tangled in a web of human connections, his carefully laid plans unraveling at the seams.

And yet, as he stood beside Dean, watching the sun set over a chaotic family gathering, he felt a sense of belonging he'd never known before. It was a strange, disorienting feeling, but one he couldn't quite bring himself to shake.

As they exchanged a look, Dean's eyes crinkling at the corners, Crowley realized that some things were worth rewriting the plan for. This life, with its messy, beautiful humanity, was one of them.

In the midst of the barbecue's chaos, Crowley turned to Dean and whispered, "You know, I never thought I'd say this, but... I think I'm starting to enjoy this whole 'family' thing."

Dean's laughter was a low, husky sound, and Crowley felt his heart twist in response. "Welcome to the Winchester family, Crowley. You're in for a wild ride."

As the night drew to a close, Crowley smiled, feeling the threads of his carefully constructed life begin to fray. He knew that he'd never be able to go back to the way things were before. Not now, not when he'd caught a glimpse of this strange, beautiful life with Dean Winchester.

And as they walked away from the barbecue, arms slung over each other's shoulders, Crowley realized that some things were worth rewriting the plan for. This life, with all its messy, wonderful humanity, was one of them.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey adjusted his tie, a habitual gesture that betrayed his growing unease as he watched the case discussion unfold. He had been working with the FBI for a while now, and his handler, Agent Peter Burke, had been riding him hard to follow procedure. Neal had always been a bit of a free spirit, content to bend the rules to get the job done. But lately, he'd been finding himself...well, not exactly defending the rules, but at least understanding their value.

This case was a particularly tricky one, with a suspect who seemed to have covered his tracks expertly. The team was brainstorming ways to catch him, and Neal had a few ideas that he knew would work. But as he opened his mouth to share them, he caught Peter's eye, and something about his handler's expression made him pause.

"We can't just go in there and start snooping around," Neal said, to his own surprise. "We need a warrant, and we need to follow procedure."

The room fell silent, with all eyes on Neal. Peter's eyebrows shot up, and he looked like he was trying not to laugh. "Neal Caffrey, defending the sanctity of the law?" he said, his voice dripping with amusement. "I never thought I'd see the day."

Neal felt his face heat up, but he stood his ground. "Hey, just because I used to be a con artist doesn't mean I don't understand the importance of doing things by the book. We can't just barge in and start accusing people without evidence. That's not how it works."

Peter chuckled, shaking his head. "I'm impressed, Neal. You're starting to sound like a real FBI agent."

Neal shot him a look, but Peter just grinned. "Sorry, sorry. I know you're just trying to do the right thing. But I have to admit, it's a little surreal to hear you defending procedure."

The team leader, Agent Diana Barrigan, intervened, her voice smooth as silk. "Let's focus on the case, shall we? Neal, what's your idea for getting that warrant?"

Neal launched into a detailed explanation of his plan, which involved using a combination of surveillance and good old-fashioned detective work to gather evidence. Peter listened intently, his expression serious, but Neal could tell he was still amused.

As the meeting broke up and the team began to disperse, Peter caught Neal's arm. "You know, I never thought I'd say this, but I think you might actually be starting to get the hang of this whole 'being a law-abiding citizen' thing."

Neal rolled his eyes. "Shut up, Peter."

But as they walked out of the conference room, Neal couldn't help but feel a sense of pride. He was still a long way from being a by-the-book kind of guy, but he was learning. And who knows, maybe one day he'd even be able to give Peter a run for his money in the "most uptight FBI agent" department.

The case itself was a challenge, but with Neal's unorthodox skills and Peter's by-the-book approach, they managed to catch the suspect and bring him to justice. As they left the courtroom, Peter turned to Neal and said, "You know, I think you might just make a decent FBI agent yet."

Neal grinned. "I'll take that as a compliment, coming from you."

Peter chuckled. "Just don't get too comfortable, Caffrey. I still don't trust you as far as I can throw you."

Neal laughed, feeling a sense of belonging he'd never thought he'd experience. "I wouldn't have it any other way, Peter."

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
"Captain, I'm telling you, it doesn't make sense," Chief Engineer Montgomery said, frustration etched on his face as he stared at the rows of dark, unresponsive consoles. "We've checked every system, every circuit, every possible malfunction. There's no reason for this ship to be dead in space."

Captain Kirk's eyes narrowed, his voice firm but controlled. "I don't pay you to tell me what doesn't make sense, Montgomery. I pay you to fix it. We're running out of time."

Montgomery felt a surge of defensiveness, but he knew the captain was right. They had to find a solution, and fast. The Enterprise was drifting, helpless, in the middle of nowhere. Theories were flying thick and fast, from solar flare to alien attack, but none of them held water.

"I'll try again, sir," Montgomery said, already knowing it was a long shot. "But I need to think outside the box here. Maybe it's not a malfunction at all."

Kirk raised an eyebrow. "What are you suggesting?"

Montgomery hesitated, unsure how to articulate his gut feeling. "I don't know, sir. It's just... sometimes, when you're too close to the problem, you can't see the solution. Maybe we need to take a step back, look at it from a different angle."

The captain's expression softened, ever so slightly. "You're thinking like a detective, Montgomery. I like that. Try it."

Montgomery took a deep breath and began to pace the engineering room, trying to clear his mind. The crew was counting on him, and he couldn't let them down. He thought back to his training, to every lesson he'd learned about starship design and operation. And then, suddenly, a tiny spark of memory ignited.

"Captain, I think I might have something," he said, spinning back to face Kirk. "Remember that minor upgrade we did last week? The one to the warp core's power matrix?"

Kirk's eyes snapped to attention. "What about it?"

Montgomery's heart was racing. "What if it wasn't a malfunction? What if someone... deliberately sabotaged the ship?"

The captain's face went white. "Impossible. We have the best security in the galaxy."

But Montgomery was undeterred. He pulled up the ship's internal sensors, scouring the data for any sign of tampering. And then, buried deep in the code, he found it – a tiny, almost imperceptible change to the warp core's programming.

"It was one of our own crew," Montgomery said, his voice barely above a whisper.

Kirk's eyes locked onto his, a fierce determination burning within them. "Find out who, Montgomery. And find out why."

As the hours ticked down, Montgomery worked tirelessly, following the digital trail of clues. It led him to an unlikely suspect – Ensign Amy K'Rhyn, the ship's newest and youngest crew member. Montgomery's gut twisted with unease as he confronted her, but to his surprise, she broke down, confessing to the sabotage.

It turned out that K'Rhyn had been coerced by a shadowy organization, threatening her family unless she carried out the deed. Montgomery felt a pang of compassion for the young ensign, realizing that even the most seemingly perfect crew could hide secrets.

With the truth finally out, Montgomery set to work repairing the damage, his fingers flying across the consoles as he worked to restore the Enterprise to life. The crew watched in silence, their faces etched with worry, but Montgomery knew he had this.

As the ship's systems roared back online, Montgomery felt a sense of pride and accomplishment wash over him. He'd solved the mystery, saved the crew, and discovered a newfound respect for the power of human intuition.

"Captain, we're back online," he said, grinning, as the Enterprise surged forward, leaving the darkness of space behind.

Kirk clapped him on the back. "Well done, Montgomery. You've proven that even in the darkest of times, there's always a solution to be found."

Montgomery smiled, feeling a sense of camaraderie with his captain and crew. He'd learned a valuable lesson – that sometimes, it takes more than just technical skill to save the day. It takes teamwork, intuition, and a willingness to think outside the box.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
The elevator doors slid open, and Neal Caffrey stepped out into the FBI's Manhattan office, flashing his trademark smile at the receptionist. "Morning, lovely. Just here for a friendly chat with Peter."

Receptionist Bethany's eyes rolled good-naturedly. "Agent Burke's waiting for you, Neal. Though I think 'friendly chat' might be stretching it today."

Neal's curiosity was piqued as he made his way to Peter's office. He found his partner pacing behind his desk, his expression grim. "Morning, Neal. We've got a problem."

A woman with a sharp jawline and an even sharper gaze stood by the window, scrutinizing Neal as if searching for a hidden flaw. "Ah, Caffrey. I'm Agent Harris, from Internal Affairs. I'm here to audit this team's activities."

Neal's instincts prickled. He didn't like being under a microscope, and he especially didn't like being under this woman's microscope. "Audit? Whatever for?"

Harris's smile was a thin, cold line. "We've had reports of a forgery, and the evidence points to you, Caffrey."

Neal's eyes narrowed. "I don't do forgeries, Agent. I do cons. Big difference."

Peter stepped forward, his voice calm and authoritative. "Agent Harris, I can vouch for Neal's integrity. He's been a valuable asset to our team."

Harris's gaze didn't waver. "I'm not here to debate Caffrey's character, Agent Burke. I'm here to uncover the truth. And if that truth implicates your partner, so be it."

Neal's mind began racing. He knew he was innocent, but he also knew how these things worked. Sometimes, it wasn't about guilt or innocence; it was about appearances. And right now, it seemed like he was the one with the target on his back.

As Harris began questioning him, Neal's frustration grew. He knew he had to clear his name, not just for himself, but for Peter, who was getting dragged into this mess by association. But how?

That night, over a plate of takeout in his apartment, Neal's mind was still spinning. He needed a plan, something that would prove his innocence and throw Harris off his scent. And then it hit him – a plan that was equal parts clever and reckless.

The next morning, Neal strolled into the office, whistling. Harris looked up from her notes, her eyes narrowing. "Caffrey, I'm not in the mood for your antics."

Neal grinned. "Oh, I'm not here to cause trouble, Agent. I'm here to help. You see, I've been thinking... maybe the forgery wasn't about me at all. Maybe it was about someone else entirely."

Harris raised an eyebrow. "Go on."

Neal launched into a tale of a rival forger, one who had been trying to discredit him for years. Harris listened intently, her expression unreadable. Neal could almost see the gears turning in her head as she considered his words.

But just as he was about to reveal the pièce de résistance, Harris's phone rang. She listened for a moment, her expression changing from skepticism to surprise. "It seems we have a development, Caffrey. A witness has come forward, claiming to have seen the real forger."

Neal's heart skipped a beat. This was it – the break he needed. "Who is it?"

Harris's eyes locked onto his. "It's someone from your past, Caffrey. Someone who says you're telling the truth."

The game was afoot. Neal's plan had worked, but now it was time to take a risk. He stood up, his eyes locked onto Harris's. "I think it's time we had a little chat with this witness, don't you, Agent?"

Harris's smile was a small, grudging thing. "After you, Caffrey."

As they left the office, Neal felt a sense of pride and trepidation. He had taken a chance, and it had paid off. But he also knew that this was far from over. There were still twists and turns to come, and he was ready to face them head-on.

For the first time in a long time, Neal felt like he was in control. And it felt amazing.

The elevator doors closed behind them, and Neal turned to Harris. "You know, Agent? I think we're going to get along just fine."

Harris raised an eyebrow. "I wouldn't count on it, Caffrey."

Neal just smiled. He knew that, sometimes, it was the unexpected alliances that led to the greatest victories.
